I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  (i)  a  proposed 
policy-based  loan  to  the  Kingdom  of  Bhutan  for  subprogram  2  of  the  Financial  Market 
Development  Program  (program),  and  (ii)  the  inclusion  of  subprogram  3  in  the  program 
(anticipated processing in 2021). The report also describes proposed technical assistance (TA) 
for  Strengthening  the  Financial  Market  Development  Program,  and  if  the  Board  approves  the 
proposed loan, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, approve the TA. 
 
2. 
The program supports key policy reforms designed to address finance sector deficiencies 
in  terms  of  institutions, markets  and  products,  vulnerabilities  caused  by  inadequate  risk-based 
supervision and concentration, and increased inclusiveness in the finance sector.1 The program 
utilizes  a  programmatic  approach  that  aligns  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  support  to  key 
government reform programs over the medium to long-term, to increase access to finance for the 
private sector and improve financial inclusion to enable economic diversification efforts in Bhutan. 
In October 2019, the ADB Board of Directors approved the programmatic approach and a $30 
million loan for subprogram 1 which was implemented from January 2018 to October 2019 was 
financially closed 31 May 2020 without any issues on record.2 Subprogram 2 is included in ADB’s 
country operations business plan, 2020–2022 for commitment in 2020.3 The program is aligned 
with  the  following  operational  priorities  of  Strategy  2030:  (i)  addressing  remaining  poverty  and 
reducing  inequalities,  (ii)  accelerating  progress  in  gender  equality,  and  (iii)  strengthening 
governance and institutional capacity.4

4. 
Development problem. Economic diversification is a significant development problem for 
Bhutan despite three decades of rapid economic growth averaging 7.0% ending fiscal year (FY) 
2018, coupled with a reduction in the national poverty rate from 23.0% in 2007 to 8.2% in 2017. 
Hydropower contributes 25.0% to the gross domestic product (GDP). A decline in the production 
of electricity because of lower-than-expected rainfall and delays in the completion of hydropower 
projects is likely to affect Bhutan’s economy adversely.6 The unemployment rate was 2.7%, with 
youth unemployment at 11.9%, as of the end of 2019. The government’s Twelfth Five Year Plan, 
2018–2023  aims  to  diversify  the  economy  by  creating  jobs  and  promoting  the  private  sector.7 
Growth in the private sector has been sluggish because of inadequate access to finance. Banks 
in  Bhutan  rely  on  collateral  and  owner’s  equity  for  lending,  which  makes  access to  finance  by 
micro, small and medium-sized enterprises (MSME) difficult. This is out of line with international 
practice, which places greater weight on financial assessments and credit history. 
 
Economic  Impact  of  COVID-19.  The  coronavirus  disease  (COVID-19)  pandemic  has 
5. 
significantly dampened growth prospects. An initial 30.0% reduction in direct tourism receipts from 
the  daily  tariff  is  estimated  for  FY2020.  While  traditionally  a  strong  driver  of  growth,  the 
construction  industry  is  facing  a  shortage  of  21,568  workers  because  of  entry  restrictions. 
Hydropower  projects  have  been  affected  by  work  stoppages  and  labor  unavailability.  ADB 
projects Bhutan’s GDP growth to contract to 2.4% in FY2020 and 1.7% in FY2021—the lowest in 
a decade.8 Post-COVID-19 fiscal deficits are targeted at 6.2% of GDP in FY2020 and 7.4% of 
GDP in FY2021. ADB disbursed $20 million in May 2020, under its COVID-19 Active Response 
and Expenditure Support Program, to complement the government’s pandemic response plan. 
This support was intended to give short-term assistance and relief in terms of access to finance 
to the MSMEs, whereas subprograms 2 and 3 under the proposed program will continue to add 
long-term budgetary support while achieving financial reforms. 
 
6. 
Significant risks to finance sector post-COVID-19. The pandemic resulted in a sharp 
increase in nonperforming loans (NPLs) as MSMEs struggled to meet debt repayments. NPLs 
were high even prior to COVID-19 due to the rapid credit growth from FY2015 to FY2019 and 
concentration in a few sectors like housing and tourism. Weakening bank balance sheets with 
high NPLs and a further breach in macro-prudential thresholds are expected.9 Although capital 
adequacy of banks is above the regulatory threshold, a decline is anticipated due to rising NPLs.10 
Nonbank finance segment is similarly challenged. Capital markets, which witnessed some growth 
in secondary trading in equity from January 2020 to February 2020, are expected to slow down, 
significantly wiping out recent gains. With an anticipated fall in dividend payouts in the corporate 
segment, stock prices are expected to fall. A lower demand for new capital will result in a decline 
in fund-raising. Insurance companies’ solvency has reduced as they now comply with RMA’s new 
solvency regulations effective from September 2019.11

Government reform agenda. The program will support the government in its commitment 
to  continue  reforms  to  make  the  finance  sector  more  responsive  to  emerging  priorities,  while 
remaining stable and inclusive. This support is critical for the government to achieve national key 
result  areas  of  the  Twelfth  Five  Year  Plan,  2018–2023,  such  as  macroeconomic  stability, 
economic  diversification,  improving  access  to  finance,  and  poverty  reduction  (footnote  7).  The 
government has prepared several long-term sector development strategies. In 2017, it approved 
the Financial Sector Development Action Plan, which details reform actions that affect, among 
others,  the  banking  system,  nonbank financial  institutions,  and  financial  inclusion  and  financial 
literacy.23 By using a programmatic approach, the program targets reforms in the nonbanking and 
finance  segment  and  promotes  financial  inclusion  to  ensure  an  increased  role  for  the  private 
sector in Bhutan’s economy. Transaction TA to deliver policy actions strengthened subprogram 2. 
 
15. 
Risk-based surveillance introduced under reforms. The Macro-Prudential Regulations 
were adopted in 2018. In 2019, risk management guidelines were issued by the RMA to provide 
minimum standards in risk mitigation at financial institutions and to ensure adoption of a sound 
risk  management  framework. 24  In  addition,  directives  on  risk-based  solvency  and  capital 
requirements  were  issued  by  RMA  for  insurance  and  reinsurance  companies  in  Bhutan  in 
September 2019.25 The RMA received support under reform area 2 of subprogram 2 on revised 
prudential guidelines to help introduce risk-based supervision and introduce relevant directives to 
financial institutions.  
 
16.

nonbank financial system, strengthening of the finance sector, and financial inclusion will continue 
to  be  delivered  under  subprogram  2.  When  subprogram  1  was  approved,  only  one  other 
subprogram (subprogram 2) was envisaged (footnote 2), but a third subprogram is now proposed 
with  further  policy  actions  in the three  reform  areas  (paras.  17–19).  The revised  post  program 
engagement  framework  after  subprogram  3  will  ensure  the  continuity  of  the  financial  market 
sector  reforms  in  several  areas.  Each  subprogram  is  a  single  tranche  intervention.  These  are 
presented in detail in the government’s Development Policy Letter (Appendix 3) and the Policy 
Matrix (Appendix 4).
